message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pertussis, and the leukocyte count supports this diagnosis. The most appropriate recommendation is to administer oral azithromycin to all family members and Tdap vaccination to the father and mother, as the mother’s Tdap vaccination is more than 10 years ago and the baby is too young to receive the vaccine. Option C is also correct, but erythromycin can cause diarrhea, which may worsen the symptoms in this case. Option A is incorrect because the baby is too young to receive azithromycin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and leukocyte count suggest pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Oral azithromycin or erythromycin can help treat the infection, and Tdap vaccination can help prevent future outbreaks. All family members, including the mother and baby, should receive antibiotics as a precautionary measure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pertussis, and the leukocyte count is elevated. The most appropriate recommendations would be to administer azithromycin to all family members and Tdap vaccination to both the father and mother. Option B is the correct answer as it includes the correct treatment for pertussis and vaccination for both parents. Option A is incorrect as the baby and the father require treatment but the mother also needs to be vaccinated. Option C is incorrect because erythromycin is no longer recommended as the first-line treatment for pertussis. Option D is incorrect because it does not include the mother receiving Tdap vaccination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with pertussis, which is highly contagious and can be fatal especially in infants. Antibiotics (azithromycin or erythromycin) are recommended to all family members to prevent transmission, and Tdap vaccination is recommended to the father and mother to prevent future infection. Option (A) does not include Tdap for the mother, and option (C) recommends erythromycin instead of azithromycin, which has been found to be less effective. Option (D) does not recommend antibiotics for the baby, who is at high risk for severe pertussis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including paroxysmal cough and post-tussive emesis, suggest pertussis infection. The leukocyte count is elevated. Family members, particularly the 2-week-old sister, are at risk for severe complications from pertussis infection. Azithromycin is the first-line antibiotic for pertussis. Tdap vaccination should be given to both parents to prevent future pertussis infections. The father's vaccination status is unknown so Tdap vaccination should be given to him as well. Erythromycin can be used as an alternative but azithromycin is preferred due to fewer side effects and better compliance. Option A only includes the father and baby, while option C includes erythromycin instead of azithromycin. Option B includes all family members and uses the preferred antibiotic while also providing Tdap vaccination to both parents. Option D includes all family members but only provides Tdap vaccination to the father.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and leukocyte count suggest the likely diagnosis is pertussis, which is highly contagious. Administering oral azithromycin to all family members and Tdap vaccination to the father and mother are the most appropriate recommendations to prevent further spread of pertussis. Option A only vaccinates the father and baby and does not provide treatment for the mother, and option C recommends the use of erythromycin which has side effects and is not the preferred treatment for pertussis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pertussis infection while the high leukocyte count indicates an acute bacterial infection. Option (B) is the most appropriate as it recommends administering oral azithromycin to all family members and Tdap vaccination to both parents. Option (A) only recommends Tdap vaccination to the father, and option (C) recommends oral erythromycin instead of azithromycin which is currently the preferred treatment for pertussis. Option (D) is similar to option (B) but does not include Tdap vaccination for the mother.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, leukocyte count, and exposure history suggest pertussis infection. Treatment with azithromycin or erythromycin is recommended for all family members. Tdap vaccination is recommended for the father and mother, and oral azithromycin is recommended for the 2-week-old sister. Option (B) is the most appropriate recommendation as it covers all necessary treatments and vaccinations for all family members.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of paroxysmal cough with posttussive emesis suggest pertussis. Being a highly contagious respiratory illness, all family members, including the 2-week-old infant, should receive oral azithromycin. Tdap vaccination should also be given to both parents to prevent further spread of the disease. Option A is incorrect because the infant also needs to receive azithromycin. Option C is incorrect because erythromycin, although effective, has a higher incidence of side effects and also interferes with hormonal contraceptives.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pertussis, which is highly contagious and spread through respiratory droplets. All family members should receive antibiotics and vaccination, with azithromycin being preferred over erythromycin in children. The mother’s Tdap vaccine is still protective, but the father’s vaccination status is unknown and he should receive it. Option A only vaccinates the father and does not include the 2-week-old baby, while option C recommends erythromycin instead of azithromycin. Option B is the most appropriate recommendation.
